case_title: RAMLAL ONKARMAL vs COMMISSIONER OF INCOME-TAX, ASSAM
complaint_summary: The Commissioner of Income-Tax alleged that the Income-Tax Officer's assessment order was erroneous and prejudicial to revenue, as it allowed a deduction of Rs. 32,759 from an unregistered firm’s loss.
investigation_summary: The Commissioner reviewed the Income-Tax Officer's records and determined that the deduction of Rs. 32,759 was contrary to the second proviso of subsection (1) of section 24 of the Income-Tax Act.
judgment_summary: The court upheld the Commissioner’s authority under section 33-B of the Income-Tax Act to revise the Income-Tax Officer’s order, even during the pendency of an appeal before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner. The court found that the Commissioner’s powers were not restricted by the pendency of an appeal.
Decision_or_verdict: Reference answered in the affirmative; Commissioner’s order under section 33-B deemed valid.

commissioner_action.reason: Loss of Rs. 32,759 from Durgapur Tea Estate should not have been set off under section 24(1) proviso

legal_issue: Validity of Commissioner’s order under section 33-B during pending appeal
legal_arguments: Section 33-B allows the Commissioner to revise erroneous orders prejudicial to revenue.
Section 31 (3)(a) grants appellate authorities power to enhance assessments.
Contrast between sections 33-A and 33-B highlights broader powers under section 33-B.
Supreme Court precedent supports Commissioner’s authority during pending appeals.

summary_vector_notes: The case revolves around the Commissioner of Income-Tax exercising revision powers under section 33-B of the Income-Tax Act to correct an erroneous assessment order by the Income-Tax Officer. The court affirmed the Commissioner’s authority, emphasizing the absence of restrictions under section 33-B, even during pending appeals. Supreme Court precedents supported this interpretation.
